ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I appreciated the ability to read information from across a variety of sources. In fact, the breadth and uniqueness of the readings led to a lot of introspection about the content - which then led to a more nuanced view of the course content.
How to critically consider museums and their practices, some very basic curating skills, particularly around developing the big idea and narrative of an exhibit!

I learned so much about the ethical, ecological, and social dynamics and dilemmas of natural historical museums. Our readings and class discussions provided me with case studies and theory through which to better understand the history and current problems and advances of these institutions.

- Submitting museum exhibition proposal 
- Working in a team
- Museum history
I acquired insights about collection histories and museum histories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoy the size of the course and the types of readings that we did. I think that some more literature on what drives the continued existence of museums (be it legislative, financial, etc.) Could have rounded out our understanding of why museums behave as they do these days. For example, what are the nuances of a "conditional gift" to a collection - more broadly. I do wish we had some more time to work on the final project as well. That helped me get to know some of my classmates better.

I loved having the exhibition proposal be such a large part of the course, as it really brought to life the issues in our readings and discussions. The one weakness of the course was that I wish we had figured out our group assignments much earlier, because I do think we would have been able to put much more long-term effort into the proposals throughout the semester.

Strengths: our class discussions were always engaging, especially because all my peers were from different graduate programs, so discussions involved a really diverse set of perspectives. The four field trips (especially our trip to the American Museum of Natural History) were probably my favorite part of the class, as we were able to apply what we had learned in readings and discussions to real-life issues at museums and conversations with curators. These were also great opportunities to ask questions that we were not able to answer in class. Finally, the proposal design process was well-set up. I appreciated that we had regular deadlines for drafting our proposal narratives so that we could receive feedback from Peabody staff. 
Weaknesses: I do wish we had started designing our proposals earlier in the semester, as things felt a bit rushed at the end.
Perhaps knowing the team for the exhibition proposal slightly earlier (just a week or two)
Great readings, but maybe we could start the proposal discussions earlier in the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course. It was a great way to learn from students and professionals in a wide set of disciplines. It also had a cool hands-on portion.
I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to other students as it really shows how complicated the historical narratives and stories of museums can be.

Yes!! This has probably been my favorite class at Yale. Since the final project was to design a proposal for a student exhibition that will be displayed at the Peabody's reopening, we got a lot of support and feedback during this process, and it felt like we were working on a project that would actually have a purpose. I also really enjoyed our readings, discussions and field trips. The field trips and discussions allowed me to apply and question what I learned in our readings. Chitra is also an amazing professor with a wealth of knowledge and experience in museums.

A resounding yes -- this course was the best for a combination of reasons, such as relevant and interesting readings, field trips to various sites and museums, and working with peers of different academic backgrounds.
Yes I would! To encourage them to learn about the history of museum institutions.

extras.title: AMST 613 01/ANTH 770 01/HIST 918 01/HSHM 777 01 - Nature and the Modern Museum
